intro: Leptopharynx parryi, commonly known as the Parry's leathery lily, is a unique flowering plant native to the high altitudes of the Andes in South America. It belongs to the family Melanthiaceae and is characterized by its striking, leathery leaves and showy, white to pinkish flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils and thrives in cool, temperate climates. Its botanical features include a short, rhizomatous stem and inflorescences that bear small, clustered flowers. Due to its habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species, making conservation efforts crucial for its survival.
